coverFootnote.value: VEST is CE marked. VEST is not yet approved for sale in the US.

eventTitle.value: VEST III RCT - International Coronary Congress 2019

screen1Body.value:
Saphenous vein grafts (SVG) are the most frequently used bypass conduits in Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG) surgery. SVG disease, early after CABG, is typically dominated by intimal hyperplasia which predisposes the graft to accelerated atherosclerosis. Arterial pressure coupled with abnormal flow patterns generated mainly by luminal irregularities are the main contributors to both focal and diffuse intimal hyperplasia.
However, despite major advances in surgical techniques and perioperative care, vein grafts continue to have high failure rates, limiting the long-term outcome of CABG. SVG failure rates range from 35% to 50% 5 to 10 years following CABG surgery. This double the risk for re-interventions.

screen1Footnote1.value: Allen K, et al. Relationship between vein graft failure and subsequent clinical outcomes after CABG; Circulation 2012:125:749-756.

screen1Footnote2.value: Harskamp RE, et al. Saphenous Vein Graft Failure after Coronary Artery Bypass Surgery Pathophysiology, Management and Future Directions. Ann Surg. 2013; 257:824-833.

screen3Body.value:
Results of randomized, controlled, clinical trials, comparing VEST supported and non-supported vein grafts up to 5 years post CABG, demonstrate that VEST mitigates the pathological remodeling of the grafts, significantly reduces intimal hyperplasia and lumen irregularities, and improves hemodynamics.
VEST is the only technology to demonstrate mitigation of intimal hyperplasia 5 years after CABG.
